articles.title: Celiac Insensitivity: A Comprehensive List of Artists Who Have Posed in Wheat Fields
articles.description: The wheat fields are calling, will you answer?
articles.content:
Hi, I’m Doran Steinfeld. I’ve been known to have a couple of issues in my life. My friend Olga Syphil, having “Among Us thumbs,” and unfortunately, also having a fucked up immune system that cannot properly digest gluten. Now, what is gluten you may ask? Well, gluten is a protein that is found in things like barley, rye, and wheat (to name a few). While this condition, known as Celiac Disease, has become more well known over time, we are still an underrepresented minority in a world where tyrannical immunotypical bigots reign supreme. So, I’d like to pose you a question. You hear about homophobic celebrities all the time - what about celiphobic celebrities? Let’s talk about them.

‍

  1. Taylor Swift.

‍

Yep. I know what you’re thinking. You’re going to go after the swifties?! Yes, I literally don’t gaf. Not only has this woman posed sillily with her head cutesy peaking into the frame, effectively mocking and teasing those of us that cannot have the fortune to do what she is doing, but she has also had her face and name mowed into an entire wheat field. Truly one of the biggest of all bosses. I don’t care if that maybe isn’t wheat in the photo of her or if she didn’t mow herself in the drone shot, it’s still connecting her to wheat, and she definitely did not do anything to try and distance herself from this negative and insulting imagery.

‍

‍

  1. Selena Gomez

‍

Don’t know much about her, sorry, and kinda don’t really care. Here’s her in wheat, mocking us by showing us how free she is being able to eat gluten, knowing that we can never experience her freedom.

‍

  1. Charli xcx

‍

The girl that made me write this article. This truly broke my heart, as a known prolific twink. This is the most clear as day photo of a celebrity posing in a wheat field. I vividly remember her posting these photos on her story with the text “lol,” further insulting and making light of a very serious situation. Add in the fact that her arms are open, trying to invite us into a place that can kill me, and it just adds insult to injury. Do better, Charli.

‍

  1. AI Beyoncé

‍

I don’t care if it’s AI. If the pathetic rumors that the toxic men spread around about her are true, Beyoncé KNOW(le)S, so she should stand up for her fans with celiac disease and squash the possible rumors that she gets along with wheat. Use that conspiracy power to kill whoever made that horrid photo!

‍

  1. Helen Mirren

‍

She may have been mother in Barbie, but she is no mother to the Celiacs. Here she plays with the wheat in her hands, toying with us, as if we’re kids in a playground and she has more toys than us. She could share, but that would be like sharing your knife with a 5 year old because of toy equality. It’s not fair, and it’s offensive.

‍

  1. Curtis Stone

‍

To be honest, I have no clue who he is. But, according to this article, he is a celebrity chef! Look, I don’t care if you cook, and so you decided to pose in a wheat field to show how skilled you are with creating dishes out of raw ingredients. By posing in front of a wheat field, you imply that you have to use wheat to create sensational meals, which is just plain wrong and hurtful to the Celiac community, as it implies that there is only one way to eat and live in life. Maybe he should venture out to more kinds of foods, it would strengthen his chef abilities.

‍

  1. Sonya Katarina

‍

Of all the people on here, this one disappointed me the most. I have been one of her 4k-ish followers for ages now, and to see her pose in this wheat field on Instagram really made me upset. To make matters worse, a fan commented on her post “#ilivefreed.” Once again going back to the dangerous rhetoric that people living with Celiac Disease are imprisoned, and not as capable or “free” as others due to the fact that they cannot pose in wheat fields like Instagram influencer Sonya.

‍

‍

  1. David Rose from Schitt’s Creek

‍

Yeah, yeah, it’s grass, but change the colors a bit and some of the shapes, and it looks EXACTLY like wheat. For the Levy family to depict a situation as serious as this and play it for laughs… Really hurtful and dangerous for people like me, and truly not what this world needs right now. Plus, add in the “cool” posture and outfit that David is in, and it just makes things even more horrible. It implies that being in and having wheat is the “cool” way to live, and that anyone who can’t isn’t cool like him. Disgusting.

‍

I hope that this article was educational and informative to those who were unaware about the severity of the situation. To tell the truth, I wasn’t sure about this article originally, but a few weeks ago the heads of Pinky Toe told us that we could be more political with our articles, and it gave me the confidence I needed to finally bring these dangerous truths to the light. I hope you all have benefited from this, and if you learn one thing, please let it be the following: STOP POSING IN WHEAT FIELDS!

‍
articles.name: Doran Steinfeld

articles.title: How to Pick Up Your Canes Order the Day of a BC Football Game as a Person of Color: Don't
articles.description: The West Campus Raising Cane's is usually a hotspot for students, but on this particular Saturday, something felt off. I walked into a sea of Boston College fans, instantly feeling outnumbered and out of place as they swarmed the restaurant like they'd never seen a chicken tender before.
articles.content:
The West Campus Raisin Canes is a wonderful addition to the Boston University campus. So much so that it attracts students from all universities across Boston. However, one school NOT in Boston is also a fan of the establishment at 949 Commonwealth Ave. And when they come, they come in pacts. It was a Saturday night, and I needed to fill my belly up before going on a bar crawl. I did not want to do dishes or cook, so placed my pickup order as I always do on Grubhub to get my 3 finger combo with an extra Texas toast and a diet Pepsi (thank you Addison Rae).

But as I walked into Canes, something felt wrong in the air . Now, Canes is usually crowded on weekends as expected, but something was different this time. First I thought I was surrounded by a bunch of high schoolers, but as I got a closer look, I noticed the dark red and gold lettering that people were wearing and I realized: I’m surrounded. I had never seen so many white people in one place on campus. I was just trying to pick up my Cane's order because getting drunk on an empty stomach is a no-go. So you could expect my confusion when I walk in and I see a bunch of Eagles trying to gentrify the Caniac combo. I was worried they thought Nick Fuentes was still a student at BU and they were here for a meet and greet.

To make matters worse, amidst the chaos erupting, someone dropped their drink on my shoe which was when I realized I got hate crimed. As a non white BU student who survived the trenches of a PWI high school, this wasn’t my first January 6th. It felt like So High School by Taylor Swift except instead of stifling my sighs, I had to stifle my childhood trauma.

I just wanted my Texas toast without feeling like I was in the actual red state. The main question I had throughout this endeavor was why they went all the way out to actual Boston just to get Canes. It would take around 30 minutes on the T to get there from their campus. It was the fan behavior for me.

I can safely say I survived but barely. So to protect yourself and your fellow POCs for the future, don’t go to the BU Raisin Canes the day of a BC football game. I’d recommend putting in your Google Calendar when their football games are so you can protect yourself and save up some money to pay for delivery instead. The only thing we can do is make sure they don’t come for El Jefe’s next.

‍
articles.name: Elana Felig

articles.title: I Went To Acapella Auditions And Ended Up At A Meeting Of A Secret Sex Cult
articles.description: What could go wrong?
articles.content:
Ever since my sexual awakening watching Anna Kendrick and Brittany Snow’s shower duet in Pitch Perfect, my dream was to join the ultra-glamorous, high-status world of collegiate a cappella.  So when auditions rolled around, I knew it was time to showcase my star quality.

I suppose the audition sign-up form should have been my first warning, but I tried to have an open mind.  I figured they were asking about my gag reflex because of the laryngeal acrobatics required to seamlessly switch vocal registers.

I knew that it was a blind audition, so I didn’t think anything of it when I stepped into the audition room and found thick velvet curtains and two people with their faces cloaked.  I did think it was a bit excessive when they handed me a mask, and it seemed strange that it was leather and shaped like a cat, but I love it when a group has a clear artistic vision.

The two cloaked figures, whose voices were disguised, had me sing several scales and match pitch.  They then began what they called my “preliminary interview,” where they asked about my flexibility and if I had good knees (to keep up with demanding competition-worthy choreography, of course).  They also asked if I had experimented with a capella before, to which I truthfully replied no, but that I was willing to do anything to make it.  That answer must have satisfied them, because they then told me that I was “ready for the next trial” and pulled back the curtain, ushering me inside.

There were several more cloaked figures behind the curtain, as well as many other masked hopefuls like myself.  Boy, they really take this blind audition thing seriously, I thought.  The auditionees were told to sort themselves into groups based on signs posted around the room: bi-curious sopranos, they/them altos, tenor bottoms, and straight male basses who had never sang before they were forced into their high school’s production of Shrek: The Musical by the drama teacher.  Once separated, we were made to sing “...Baby One More Time” by Britney Spears on an endless loop while performing the authentic music video choreography.  As sang, danced, and slayed, the cloaked figures slowly encircled us, tapping those who were unworthy of the honor of a spot in a group (or who simply lacked the stamina to continue) on the shoulder silently, sending them sobbing uncontrollably out of the room.

At last, the ritual ceased.  There were ten of us left: the chosen all-talented few!  We had made it!  I was utterly elated.  Finally, I could live out my Pitch Perfect dreams.

We were drafted into the groups that wanted us: the Bottom Splits, the Throat Goats, and the all-male group, the Twink-le Tones.  I was welcomed with open arms and open legs (it seemed an odd sitting position but who am I to judge what’s comfortable?) into the Bottom Splits!

The next day I was summoned to my first rehearsal, which began rather strangely.  I and my fellow newbies were given a pledge of secrecy to sign in blood in which we had to swore not to divulge any of the events that occurred during official a capella-sanctioned gatherings.  When the oaths were made official, the president of the group stepped to the front of the room and announced that this rehearsal would be devoted to “group bondage.”  I was sure she meant “bonding.”  I quickly discovered that I was, indeed, quite mistaken.

Before my very eyes, all of the veteran vocalists began to strip!  I found myself in a pool of flesh, hormones, and debauchery, the likes of which has not graced a stage since the Broadway premiere of Spring Awakening.  I couldn’t believe my ears when I witnessed a ménage à trois moan in a perfect D minor triad!

It was suddenly clear to me what I had gotten myself into: the singing was merely a guise—these glorified theater freaks were all fucking each other!  How could I have been so blind!

Anyways, I will be back next week.

‍
articles.name: Emma Santos
